## Load packages and data

```{r load-packages, message=FALSE}
library(tidyverse) 
library(datasauRus)
data("datasaurus_dozen")
```

## Exercises

### Exercise 1

There are 1846 rows and 3 columns in datasaurus_dozen. The three variables are dataset, x, and y.

### Exercise 2

```{r plot-dino, fig.height=3, fig.width=6}
dino_data <- datasaurus_dozen %>%
  filter(dataset == "dino")

ggplot(data = dino_data, mapping = aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point()
```

```{r cor-dino}
dino_data %>%
  summarize(r = cor(x, y))
```

It is important to visualize the data before analyzing it statistically. In this case, we can see clearly that the graph is non-linear; therefore, it doesn't make sense to test the correlation between the x and y.

### Exercise 3

Here, I plotted the star dataset and calculated the correlation coefficient between x and y in star.

```{r plot-star}
star_data <- datasaurus_dozen %>%
  filter(dataset == "star")

ggplot(data = star_data, mapping = aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point()
```

```{r cor-star}
star_data %>%
  summarize(r = cor(x, y))
```
Similar to the dino dataset, the x and y of star are used to plot a representation of a object, a star. Therefore, the correlation coefficient here is not meaningful.
